## Productions

The PXL2000 was used by [Linklater](Richard)(Richard Linklater) in his 1991 debut film, *[Slacker](Slacker (film))*.  A roughly two-minute performance art sequence within the film is shot entirely in PixelVision.

[Ahwesh](Peggy)(Peggy Ahwesh)'s *Strange Weather* (1993), which follows several [cocaine addicts](crack)(cocaine) in Florida, was shot entirely on a PXL2000. This video relies heavily on the camera's portability to maintain an intimate presence.

Video artist [Benning](Sadie)(Sadie Benning) is among the most critically acclaimed pioneers of the PXL2000, one of which was given to them by their father [Benning](James)(James Benning (film director)) around the age of 15. Benning's early video diary works gained popularity in the artist market, earning them a lasting reputation as an innovator, with an important presence in video art.

[Almereyda](Michael)(Michael Almereyda) used the camera for several of his films. *[Girl Another Planet](Another)(Another Girl Another Planet (film))* (1992) and his short *Aliens* (1993) were shot with it entirely, it was used for [of view shot](point)(point of view shot)s of the title character in *[Nadja](Nadja (film))* (1994), and it was used by the title character to make video diaries in [*Hamlet*](Hamlet (2000 film)) (2000).

The camera has been used for several music videos, including "Mote" by [Youth](Sonic)(Sonic Youth) and "Black Grease" by [Black Angels](the)(The Black Angels (band)).

Artist John Humphrey's 2003 video, *Pee Wee Goes to Prison* was shot on a PXL2000, employing a cast of dolls and other toys to stage the imaginary trial, incarceration, and eventual pardoning (by newly-elected president [Ventura](Jesse)(Jesse Ventura)) of [Herman](Pee-wee)(Pee-wee Herman) for the sale of [Yohimbe](Yohimbe).

The PXL2000 was used by the characters Maggie ([Hathaway](Anne)(Anne Hathaway)) and Jamie ([Gyllenhaal](Jake)(Jake Gyllenhaal)) in the 2010 film, *[& Other Drugs](Love)(Love & Other Drugs)*, although the black and white footage from the camera is shown at full film resolution.[Movie reviews: Love & Other Drugs](http://www.latinoreview.com/movie-reviews/love-and-other-drugs-878)

In 2018, Toronto filmmaker Karma Todd Wiseman used a PXL2000 to shoot key scenes, processing the footage with enhanced monochrome. The custom PXL2000 camera was fitted with windshield mount suction cups and painted with the red and white paint scheme of the Canadian flag.

The PXL2000 was used by the characters Melody and Jess during the show [81](Archive)(Archive 81).
Filmmaker Richard Linklater used the PXL2000 in his 1991 debut film Slacker.

## Career

Cromwell's first television performance was in a 1974 episode of *[Rockford Files](The)(The Rockford Files)* playing Terry, a tennis instructor. A few weeks later, he began a recurring role as Stretch Cunningham on *[in the Family](All)(All in the Family)*. In 1975, he took his first lead role on television as Bill Lewis in the short-lived *[l Baltimore](Hot)(Hot l Baltimore)*, and appeared on *[M*A*S*H](M*A*S*H (TV series))* as Captain Leo Bardonaro in the episode "Last Laugh". A year later, he made his film debut in [Simon](Neil)(Neil Simon)'s classic detective spoof *[by Death](Murder)(Murder by Death)*. Cromwell portrayed four different characters in four episodes of *[Miller](Barney)(Barney Miller)* (1977-1981).

In 1977 he appeared in [Company](Three's)(Three's Company) episode- "Chrissy's Night Out" as Detective Lannigan.

In 1980, Cromwell guest-starred in the two-part episode "Laura Ingalls Wilder" of the long-running television series *[House on the Prairie](Little)(Little House on the Prairie (TV series))*. He played Harve Miller, one of Almanzo Wilder's old friends.

While Cromwell continued with regular television work throughout the 1980s, he made appearances in films with supporting roles in *[Tank](Tank (film))* and *[of the Nerds](Revenge)(Revenge of the Nerds)* (both 1984). He guest starred on the sitcom *[Court](Night)(Night Court)*, playing a mental patient, along with [Peter Hall](Kevin)(Kevin Peter Hall). He had starring roles in the critically acclaimed films *[Babe](Babe (film))* (1995), *[People vs. Larry Flynt](The)(The People vs. Larry Flynt)* (1996), *[Education of Little Tree](The)(The Education of Little Tree (film))* (1997), *[Confidential](L.A.)(L.A. Confidential (film))* (1997), *[Green Mile](The)(The Green Mile (film))* (1999), ''[General's Daughter](The)(The General's Daughter (film))*, (1999) and *[Falling on Cedars](Snow)(Snow Falling on Cedars (film))'' (1999). Cromwell's first *[Trek](Star)(Star Trek)* role was on *[Trek: The Next Generation](Star)(Star Trek: The Next Generation)* in 1990, in the season 3 episode "[Hunted](The)(The Hunted (Star Trek: The Next Generation))", followed by the 1993 episode "[Part 1](Birthright,)(Birthright (Star Trek: The Next Generation))" as Jaglom Shrek. He also played Dr. [Cochrane](Zefram)(Zefram Cochrane) in *[Trek: First Contact](Star)(Star Trek: First Contact)* (1996), the *[Trek: Enterprise](Star)(Star Trek: Enterprise)* pilot episode "[Bow](Broken)(Broken Bow (Star Trek: Enterprise))", and the 2022 *[Trek: Lower Decks](Star)(Star Trek: Lower Decks)* season 3 premiere episode, "Grounded". The *Star Trek: Enterprise* episode "[a Mirror, Darkly](In)(In a Mirror, Darkly)" reused some of the *First Contact* footage. Cromwell appeared in another *Star Trek* role on the television series *[Space Nine](Deep)(Deep Space Nine)*, in the episode "[Down](Starship)(Starship Down)" as Hanok. He also voiced the Colonel in [DreamWorks](DreamWorks Animation)' *[Stallion of the Cimarron](Spirit:)(Spirit: Stallion of the Cimarron)*.

Cromwell's role as newspaper tycoon [Randolph Hearst](William)(William Randolph Hearst) in the television film *[281](RKO)(RKO 281)* earned him an [Award nomination for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Television Movie](Emmy)(Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Supporting Actor – Miniseries or a Movie). The following year, he received his second Emmy Award nomination for playing Bishop Lionel Stewart on the [NBC](NBC) medical drama series *[ER](ER (TV series))*. In 2004, he guest-starred as former President D. Wire Newman in *[West Wing](The)(The West Wing)* episode "[Stormy Present](The)(The Stormy Present)". From 2003 to 2005, Cromwell played [Sibley](George)(George Sibley (Six Feet Under)) in the [HBO](HBO) drama series *[Feet Under](Six)(Six Feet Under (TV series))*, which earned him his third Emmy Award nomination in 2003. Along with the rest of his castmates, he was also nominated for two [Actors Guild Awards for Best Ensemble in a Drama Series](Screen)(Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by an Ensemble in a Drama Series) in 2005 and 2006. The following year, Cromwell played [Philip, Duke of Edinburgh](Prince)(Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh) in *[Queen](The)(The Queen (2006 film))* (2006), that earned [Mirren](Helen)(Helen Mirren) an [Award for Best Actress](Academy)(Academy Award for Best Actress). He also guest starred as [Bauer](Phillip)(List of 24 characters#Phillip Bauer), father of lead character [Jack](Jack Bauer), in the [season](sixth)(24 (season 6)) of the [Fox](Fox Broadcasting Company) thriller drama series *[24](24 (TV series))*.

In October 2007, Cromwell played the lead role of James Tyrone Sr. in the [Theatre Company](Druid)(Druid Theatre Company)'s production of [O'Neill](Eugene)(Eugene O'Neill)'s ''[Day's Journey into Night](Long)(Long Day's Journey into Night)'', at the [in Dublin](Gaiety)(Gaiety Theatre, Dublin) as part of the [Bank Dublin Theatre Festival's](Ulster)(Dublin Theatre Festival) 50th Anniversary.[Gaiety Theatre Dublin, Ireland – Irish Theatre](http://www.gaietytheatre.ie/shows/LongDaysJourneyIntoNight.htm)  That same year he received the King Vidor Memorial Award from the [Luis Obispo International Film Festival](San)(San Luis Obispo International Film Festival) for his artistic achievements in film. Cromwell played [H. W. Bush](George)(George H. W. Bush) in [Stone](Oliver)(Oliver Stone)'s *[W.](W. (film))* (2008), that chronicles the rise to power of [son](Bush's)(George W. Bush) up until the [invasion of Iraq](2003)(2003 invasion of Iraq). Cromwell also provided the voice of the main villain Professor Robert Callaghan/Yokai in the Disney movie *[Hero 6](Big)(Big Hero 6 (film))*.

In 2015, Cromwell executive produced the documentary *[Threat](Imminent)(Imminent Threat)* which tackles the War on Terror's impact on civil liberties.

In 2016 Cromwell starred in [HBO](HBO)'s series *[Young Pope](The)(The Young Pope)* alongside [Law](Jude)(Jude Law) and [Keaton](Diane)(Diane Keaton). In 2018, he appeared in [HBO](HBO)'s *[Succession](Succession (TV series))*, and [Starz](Starz)'s *[Counterpart](Counterpart (TV series))*.

In 2020, Cromwell starred in the Australian comedy-drama film *[Too Late](Never)(Never Too Late (2020 film))*.Maddox, Garry (16 April 2019) [Life is still busy over 70 for stars of new 'triumph over ageing' film](https://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/movies/life-is-still-busy-over-70-for-stars-of-new-triumph-over-ageing-film-20190408-p51bxg.html), *[Sydney Morning Herald](The)(The Sydney Morning Herald)*. Retrieved 20 February 2020. Cromwell starred in *[Buffalo](Operation)(Operation Buffalo (TV series))*, an Australian television comedy-drama series about the atomic bomb tests in outback Australia, which screened on [ABC](ABC TV (Australian TV network)) from 31 May 2020.

He is currently featured in the [Max](HBO)(HBO Max) show *[Julia](Julia (2022 TV series))*, as Julia Child's father, John McWilliams.

In 2021, Cromwell executive produced the psychedelic comedy *[Hollywoodland](Mondo)(Mondo Hollywoodland)*, directed by Janek Ambros, who also directed *Imminent Threat*.
James Cromwell played George Sibley on the HBO drama series Six Feet Under (2003–2005).

## Early life

He was born Alfredo Molina on 24 May 1953 in the [Paddington](Paddington) district of London. His father, Esteban J. Molina, was a Spanish immigrant from [Murcia](Murcia), who came to England in 1939, and worked as a waiter and chauffeur. His mother, Giovanna (née Bonelli), was an Italian immigrant who moved to Britain after [War II](World)(World War II), and who cleaned rooms in a hotel, and worked as a cook and housekeeper. Molina grew up in a working-class district in [Hill](Notting)(Notting Hill) that was inhabited by many other immigrant families. He attended a Roman Catholic secondary school there. He decided to become an actor after seeing *[Spartacus](Spartacus (film))* at the age of nine, and attended the [School of Music and Drama](Guildhall)(Guildhall School of Music and Drama), as well as auditioning for and becoming a member of the [Youth Theatre](National)(National Youth Theatre). At the age of 21, he changed his name to Alfred, at the urging of his first agent.
He attended the Guildhall School of Music and Drama in London.

## Legacy and influence

According to guitarist [Van Zandt](Stevie)(Stevie Van Zandt) of the [Street Band](E)(E Street Band), Spector was a "genius irredeemably conflicted". On Twitter, he wrote: "[Spector] was the ultimate example of the art always being better than the artist... [He] made some of the greatest records in history based on the salvation of love while remaining incapable of giving or receiving love his whole life."

Spector is often called the first [auteur](auteur) among musical artists for acting not only as a producer, but also the creative director, writing or choosing the material, supervising the arrangements, conducting the vocalists and [musician](session)(session musician)s, and masterminding all phases of the recording process. He helped pave the way for [rock](art)(art rock), and helped inspire the emergence of aesthetically oriented genres such as [shoegaze](shoegaze) and [music](noise)(noise music). *[PopMatters](PopMatters)* editor [Bergstrom](John)(John Bergstrom) credits the start of [pop](dream)(dream pop) to Spector's collaboration with George Harrison on *All Things Must Pass*.

His influence has been claimed by performers such as [Beatles](the)(the Beatles), [Beach Boys](the)(the Beach Boys), and [Velvet Underground](the)(the Velvet Underground) alongside latter-day record producers such as [Eno](Brian)(Brian Eno) and [Visconti](Tony)(Tony Visconti). [rock](Alternative)(Alternative rock) performers [Twins](Cocteau)(Cocteau Twins), [Bloody Valentine](My)(My Bloody Valentine (band)), and [Jesus and Mary Chain](the)(the Jesus and Mary Chain) have all cited Spector as an influence. [Shoegaze](Shoegaze), a British musical movement in the late 1980s to mid-1990s, was heavily influenced by the Wall of Sound. [Pierce](Jason)(Jason Pierce) of [Spiritualized](Spiritualized) has cited Spector as a major influence on his *[It Come Down](Let)(Let It Come Down (Spiritualized album))* album. [Gillespie](Bobby)(Bobby Gillespie) of [Scream](Primal)(Primal Scream) and [Jesus and Mary Chain](the)(the Jesus and Mary Chain) has enthused about Spector, with the song "[Like Honey](Just)(Just Like Honey)" opening with an homage of the famous "Be My Baby" drum intro.

Many have tried to emulate Spector's methods, and [Wilson](Brian)(Brian Wilson) of the Beach Boys—a fellow adherent of mono recording—considered Spector his main competition as a studio artist. In the 1960s, Wilson thought of Spector as "the single most influential producer. He's timeless. He makes a milestone whenever he goes into the studio." Wilson's fascination with Spector's work has persisted for decades, with many different references to Spector and his work scattered around Wilson's songs with the Beach Boys and even his solo career. Of Spector-related productions, Wilson has been involved with covers of "[My Baby](Be)(Be My Baby)", "[of Love](Chapel)(Chapel of Love)", "[Once in My Life](Just)(Just Once in My Life)", "[No Other (Like My Baby)](There's)(There's No Other (Like My Baby))", "[He Kissed Me](Then)(Then He Kissed Me)", "[to Me](Talk)(Talk to Me (Joe Seneca song))", "[Don't They Let Us Fall in Love](Why)(Why Don't They Let Us Fall in Love)", "[Lost That Lovin' Feelin'](You've)(You've Lost That Lovin' Feelin')", "[Doo Ron Ron](Da)(Da Doo Ron Ron)", "[Can Hear Music](I)(I Can Hear Music)", and "This Could Be the Night".

[Franz](Johnny)(Johnny Franz)'s mid-1960s productions for [Springfield](Dusty)(Dusty Springfield) and [Walker Brothers](the)(the Walker Brothers) also employed a layered, symphonic "Wall of Sound" arrangement-and-recording style, heavily influenced by the Spector sound. Another example is the Forum, a studio project of [Baxter](Les)(Les Baxter), which produced a minor hit in 1967 with "[River Is Wide](The)(The River Is Wide)". [Bono](Sonny)(Sonny Bono), a former associate of Spector's, developed a jangly, guitar-laden variation on the Spector sound, which is heard mainly in mid-1960s productions for his then-wife [Cher](Cher), notably "[Bang (My Baby Shot Me Down)](Bang)(Bang Bang (My Baby Shot Me Down))".

[Springsteen](Bruce)(Bruce Springsteen) emulated the Wall of Sound technique in his recording of "[to Run](Born)(Born to Run (Bruce Springsteen song))". In 1973, the British band [Wizzard](Wizzard), led by [Wood](Roy)(Roy Wood), had three Spector-influenced hits with "[My Baby Jive](See)(See My Baby Jive)", "[Fingers (A Teen Ballad)](Angel)(Angel Fingers (A Teen Ballad))", and "[Wish It Could Be Christmas Everyday](I)(I Wish It Could Be Christmas Everyday)", the latter becoming a perennial Christmas hit. Other contemporaries influenced by Spector include [Morton](George)(Shadow Morton), [& Cher](Sonny)(Sonny & Cher), [Rolling Stones](the)(the Rolling Stones), [Four Tops](the)(the Four Tops), [Wirtz](Mark)(Mark Wirtz), [Lovin' Spoonful](the)(the Lovin' Spoonful), and [Beatles](the)(the Beatles). Swedish pop group [ABBA](ABBA) cited Spector as an influence, and used similar Wall of Sound techniques in their early songs, including "[Ring](Ring)(Ring Ring (ABBA song))", "[Waterloo](Waterloo (ABBA song))", and "[Queen](Dancing)(Dancing Queen)". The Los Angeles-based [wave](new)(new wave music) band [of Voodoo](Wall)(Wall of Voodoo) takes their name from Spector's Wall of Sound. Spector's influence is also felt in other areas of the world, especially Japan. [pop](City)(City pop) musician [Ohtaki](Eiichi)(Eiichi Ohtaki) has been influenced by Spector and the Wall of Sound.

**Harvey Phillip Spector** (December 26, 1939January 16, 2021) was an American record producer and songwriter. He is best known for his innovative recording practices in the 1960s and development of the [of Sound](Wall)(Wall of Sound), a production style that is characterized for its diffusion of [color](tone)(tone color)s and dense orchestral sound, which he described as a "[Wagnerian](Richard Wagner)" approach to [and roll](rock)(rock and roll). He is widely regarded as one of the most influential figures in [music](pop)(pop music) history and one of the most successful producers of the 1960s. In the 2000s, Spector was [tried for and convicted of murder](was)(Murder of Lana Clarkson) and sentenced to 19 years in prison.

Born in [Bronx](the)(the Bronx), Spector moved to Los Angeles as a teenager and began his career in 1958 as a founding member of [Teddy Bears](the)(the Teddy Bears), for whom he penned "[Know Him Is to Love Him](To)(To Know Him Is to Love Him)", a U.S. number-one hit. In 1960, after working as an apprentice to [and Stoller](Leiber)(Leiber and Stoller), Spector co-founded [Records](Philles)(Philles Records), and at the age of 21 became the youngest ever U.S. label owner to that point. Dubbed the "[Tycoon of Teen](First)(Honorific nicknames in popular music)", (This appears in the microfilm edition of the *Herald Tribune* but apparently not in the online database) Spector came to be considered the first [auteur](auteur) of the music industry for the unprecedented control he had over every phase of the recording process. He produced acts such as [Ronettes](the)(the Ronettes), [Crystals](the)(the Crystals), and [& Tina Turner](Ike)(Ike & Tina Turner), and typically collaborated with arranger [Nitzsche](Jack)(Jack Nitzsche) and engineer [Levine](Larry)(Larry Levine). The musicians from his *de facto* [band](house)(house band), later known as "[Wrecking Crew](the)(the Wrecking Crew (music))", rose to industry fame through his hit records.

In the early 1970s, Spector produced [Beatles](the)(the Beatles)' *[It Be](Let)(Let It Be (Beatles album))* and several solo records by [Lennon](John)(John Lennon) and [Harrison](George)(George Harrison). By the mid-1970s Spector had produced eighteen U.S. Top 10 singles for various artists. His chart-toppers included [Righteous Brothers](the)(the Righteous Brothers)' "[Lost That Lovin' Feelin'](You've)(You've Lost That Lovin' Feelin')", the Beatles' "[Long and Winding Road](The)(The Long and Winding Road)", and Harrison's "[Sweet Lord](My)(My Sweet Lord)". Following one-off productions for [Cohen](Leonard)(Leonard Cohen) (''[of a Ladies' Man](Death)(Death of a Ladies' Man (album))*), [DiMucci](Dion)(Dion DiMucci) (*[to Be with You](Born)(Born to Be with You (album))*), and the [Ramones](Ramones) (*[of the Century](End)(End of the Century)''), Spector remained largely inactive amid a lifestyle of seclusion, drug use, and increasingly erratic behavior.

Spector helped establish the role of the [as an instrument](studio)(Recording studio as an instrument), the integration of [art](pop)(pop art) aesthetics into music ([pop](art)(art pop)), and the genres of [rock](art)(art rock) and [pop](dream)(dream pop). His honors include the 1973 [Award for Album of the Year](Grammy)(Grammy Award for Album of the Year) for co-producing Harrison's *[for Bangladesh](Concert)(The Concert for Bangladesh (album))*, a 1989 induction into the [and Roll Hall of Fame](Rock)(Rock and Roll Hall of Fame), and a 1997 induction into the [Hall of Fame](Songwriters)(Songwriters Hall of Fame). In 2004, Spector was ranked number 63 on *[Stone](Rolling)(Rolling Stone)*s list of the [artists in history](greatest)(Rolling Stone's 100 Greatest Artists of All Time).See:

*

*  In 2009, after two decades in semi-retirement, he was convicted of the 2003 murder of actress [Clarkson](Lana)(Lana Clarkson) and sentenced to 19 years to life in prison, where he died in 2021.

## Early life

Smit-McPhee was born on 13 June 1996 in [Adelaide](Adelaide), South Australia, the son of Sonja Smit and Andy McPhee. His father is an actor and former professional wrestler. His older sister is actress and singer [Smit-McPhee](Sianoa)(Sianoa Smit-McPhee).

At age 16, Smit-McPhee was diagnosed with [spondylitis](ankylosing)(ankylosing spondylitis), a degenerative form of [arthritis](arthritis) which causes vertebrae in the spine to fuse and can lead to chronic pain and loss of vision. Due to the condition, he is [blind](Blindness) in his left eye.
He was diagnosed with ankylosing spondylitis (spondylitis) at age 16, which led to blindness in his left eye.

### Adoption and formalisation of the Commonwealth

In the [Declaration](Balfour)(Balfour Declaration of 1926) at the [Imperial Conference](1926)(1926 Imperial Conference), the United Kingdom and its dominions agreed they were "equal in status, in no way subordinate one to another in any aspect of their domestic or external affairs, though united by common allegiance to the Crown, and freely associated as members of the British Commonwealth of Nations". The term "[Commonwealth](Commonwealth)" was officially adopted to describe the community.

These aspects to the relationship were formalised by the [of Westminster](Statute)(Statute of Westminster 1931) in 1931, which applied to Canada without the need for ratification, but Australia, [Zealand](New)(New Zealand), and [Newfoundland](Dominion of Newfoundland) had to ratify the statute for it to take effect. Newfoundland never did as due to economic hardship and the need for financial assistance from London, Newfoundland voluntarily accepted the suspension of self-government in 1934 and governance reverted to direct control from London. Newfoundland later joined Canada as its [province](tenth)(Provinces and territories of Canada) in 1949. [Australia](Australia) and New Zealand ratified the Statute in [1942](Statute of Westminster Adoption Act 1942) and [1947](Statute of Westminster Adoption Act 1947) respectively.

Although the Union of South Africa was not among the Dominions that needed to adopt the Statute of Westminster for it to take effect, two laws—the Status of the Union Act, 1934, and the Royal Executive Functions and Seals Act of 1934—were passed to confirm South Africa's status as a sovereign state.

### Postwar

During the Second World War, the British Empire played a major role in supporting British finances.  Foreign exchange reserves were pooled in London, to be used to fight the war.  In effect the United Kingdom procured £2.3 billion, of which £1.3 billion was from India.  The debt was held in the form of British government securities and became known as "sterling balances". By 1950, India, Pakistan and Ceylon had spent much of their sterling, while other countries accumulated more. The sterling area included all of the Commonwealth except for Canada, together with some smaller countries especially in the Persian Gulf.  They held their foreign-exchange in sterling, protecting that currency from runs and facilitating trade and investment inside the Commonwealth.  It was a formal relationship with fixed exchange rates, periodic meetings at Commonwealth summits to coordinate trade policy, and domestic economic policies. The United Kingdom ran a trade surplus, and the other countries were mostly producers of raw materials sold to the United Kingdom.  The commercial rationale was gradually less attractive to the Commonwealth; however, access to the growing London capital market remained an important advantage to the newly independent nations.  As the United Kingdom moved increasingly close to Europe, however, the long-term ties began to be in doubt.Catherine R. Schenk,  "Britain in the world economy." in Paul Addison and Harriet Jones, eds., *A Companion to Contemporary Britain: 1939–2000* (2005): 436–481, esp. 469-71.
1949 — the London Declaration (issued 28 April 1949) formally constituted the Commonwealth of Nations.

## Contracts for marriage

Lady Jane acted as chief mourner at Catherine Parr's funeral; Thomas Seymour showed continued interest to keep her in his household, and she returned there for about two months before he was arrested at the end of 1548. Seymour's brother, the [Protector](Lord)(Lord Protector), [Seymour, 1st Duke of Somerset](Edward)(Edward Seymour, 1st Duke of Somerset), felt threatened by Thomas' popularity with the young King Edward. Among other things, Thomas Seymour was charged with proposing Jane as a bride for the king.

In the course of Thomas Seymour's following [attainder](attainder) and execution, Jane's father was lucky to stay largely out of trouble. After his fourth interrogation by the [Council](King's)(Privy Council of England), he proposed his daughter Jane as a bride for the Protector's eldest son, [Hertford](Lord)(Edward Seymour, 1st Earl of Hertford). Nothing came of this, however, and Jane was not engaged until 25 May 1553, her bridegroom being [Guildford Dudley](Lord)(Lord Guildford Dudley), a younger son of [Dudley, 1st Duke of Northumberland](John)(John Dudley, 1st Duke of Northumberland). The Duke, [President](Lord)(Lord President of the Council) of the [Council](King's)(privy council) from late 1549, was then the most powerful man in the country. On 25 May 1553, the couple were married at [House](Durham)(Durham House (London)) in a triple wedding, in which Jane's sister [Catherine](Lady Catherine Grey) was matched with the heir of the [of Pembroke](Earl)(William Herbert, 1st Earl of Pembroke (1551 creation)), [Herbert](Lord)(Henry Herbert, 2nd Earl of Pembroke), and another [Katherine](Katherine Hastings, Countess of Huntingdon), Lord Guildford's sister, with [Hastings](Henry)(Henry Hastings, 3rd Earl of Huntingdon), the [of Huntingdon](Earl)(Francis Hastings, 2nd Earl of Huntingdon)'s heir.; .
Lady Jane Grey was married to Lord Guildford Dudley (Guildford Dudley), a younger son of John Dudley, 1st Duke of Northumberland. They married on 25 May 1553.

## Personal life

[[File:Homecoming 13 (44747938721) (cropped).jpg|thumb|upright|Rossum and her husband [Esmail](Sam)(Sam Esmail) in September 2018]]

Rossum married Justin Siegel on February 17, 2008, though they publicly presented themselves as in a relationship but unmarried. He filed for divorce 19 months later on September 25, 2009, in Los Angeles, citing irreconcilable differences, and the divorce was finalized on December 28, 2010. In August 2015, Rossum became engaged to writer/director [Esmail](Sam)(Sam Esmail) after two years of dating, and the couple married on May 29, 2017, at a [Reform](Reform Judaism) synagogue in New York City. Rossum gave birth to their daughter on May 23, 2021, after keeping her pregnancy a secret from the media. On April 6, 2023, Rossum made a surprise announcement on her Instagram account that she and Esmail welcomed their son the previous day.

She is a relative, by marriage, of designer [Wang](Vera)(Vera Wang), who was married to Rossum's cousin, investor and real-estate developer [P. Becker](Arthur)(Arthur P. Becker). Rossum has described herself as "[spiritual person, but not especially religious](a)(Spiritual but not religious)."

## Early life

Emmanuelle Grey Rossum was born on September 12, 1986, in New York City. She is the only child of Cheryl Rossum, a single mother who worked as a corporate photographer. Her parents separated while her mother was pregnant, and as of 2007, she had met her father only twice.

Rossum's mother is Jewish of [Jewish](Russian)(History of the Jews in Russia) descent, and her father is [Protestant](Protestant) of English and Dutch ancestry. Rossum identifies as Jewish and has stated that her mother instilled in her the "Jewish code of ethics and morals". She was named for her great-grandfather, whose first name was Emanuel, using the feminine spelling.

Upon singing "[Birthday](Happy)(Happy Birthday to You)" in all 12 keys,Joffe, Jessica. "Emmy Rossum: Hollywood's newest It Girl." Glamour: September 2006. p 326-7, 392 Rossum was welcomed to join the [Opera](Metropolitan)(Metropolitan Opera) Children's Chorus by chorus director Elena Doria at age seven. Over the course of five years she sang onstage with the chorus and had the chance to perform with singers such as [Domingo](Plácido)(Plácido Domingo) and [Pavarotti](Luciano)(Luciano Pavarotti). For anywhere from $5 to $10 a night, Rossum sang in six languages in 20 operas, including *[bohème](La)(La bohème)*, *[Turandot](Turandot)*, a [Hall](Carnegie)(Carnegie Hall) presentation of *[damnation de Faust](La)(La damnation de Faust)*, and ''[ A Midsummer Night's Dream](A Midsummer Night's Dream (opera) )''."It's Evening in America". *[Fair](Vanity)(Vanity Fair (magazine))*. May 2012. Page 152. She also worked under the direction of [Zeffirelli](Franco)(Franco Zeffirelli) in *[Carmen](Carmen)*.

An increasing interest in pursuing acting led to taking classes with Flo Salant Greenberg of [New Actors Workshop](The)(The New Actors Workshop) in New York City. She has also worked with acting coach Terry Knickerbocker.

Rossum attended the [School](Spence)(Spence School), a private school in [Manhattan](Manhattan), before dropping out to pursue career opportunities. She received her high school diploma at fifteen years old via online-extension courses offered by [University](Stanford)(Stanford University)'s [Program for Gifted Youth](Education)(Education Program for Gifted Youth) (EPGY). She enrolled at [University](Columbia)(Columbia University), studying French, art history and philosophy.
She enrolled at Columbia University in New York City, where she studied French, art history and philosophy.

### Time in Texas and Juneteenth

[[File:General Order No. 3.jpg|thumb|right|[Order No. 3](General)(General Order No. 3), June 19, 1865]]When the war ended, Granger was given command of the [of Texas](District)(Department of Texas).Dupuy, p. 290 On June 19, 1865, in the city of [Galveston](Galveston, Texas), one of the first orders of business was to read to the people of Texas Granger's [Order No. 3](General)(General Order No. 3) which began with:[From Texas: Important Orders by General Granger.](https://www.nytimes.com/1865/07/07/news/texas-important-orders-general-granger-surrender-senator-johnson-arkansas.html) *The New York Times,* July 7, 1865.

This set off joyous demonstrations by the freed people, originating the annual [Juneteenth](Juneteenth) celebration, which commemorates the abolition of slavery in Texas.
Union Major General Gordon Granger. He issued General Order No. 3 in Galveston, Texas, on June 19, 1865, which announced the enforcement of emancipation and sparked the Juneteenth celebrations.

That phrase appears in the Quran in Surah al-Anʿām (Chapter 6), verse 54.

Arabic (beginning of the verse): 
وَإِذَا جَاءَكَ الَّذِينَ يُؤْمِنُونَ بِآيَاتِنَا فَقُلْ سَلَامٌ عَلَيْكُمْ ۖ كَتَبَ رَبُّكُمْ عَلَىٰ نَفْسِهِ الرَّحْمَةَ...

Common English translation (e.g. Sahih International): 
"And when those come to you who believe in Our verses, say, 'Peace be upon you. Your Lord has decreed upon Himself mercy...' "

## Trial and execution

Referred to by the court as Jane Dudley, wife of Guildford, Jane was charged with [treason](high)(high treason), as were her husband, two of his brothers, and the former [of Canterbury](archbishop)(archbishop of Canterbury), [Cranmer](Thomas)(Thomas Cranmer). Their trial, by a special commission, took place on 13 November 1553, at [Guildhall](Guildhall, London) in the [of London](City)(City of London). The commission was chaired by [Thomas White](Sir)(Thomas White (merchant)), [Mayor of London](Lord)(Lord Mayor of London), and [Howard, 3rd Duke of Norfolk](Thomas)(Thomas Howard, 3rd Duke of Norfolk). Other members included [Stanley, 3rd Earl of Derby](Edward)(Edward Stanley, 3rd Earl of Derby), and [Bourchier, 2nd Earl of Bath](John)(John Bourchier, 2nd Earl of Bath). As was to be expected, all defendants were found guilty and sentenced to death. Jane's guilt, of having treacherously assumed the title and the power of the monarch, was evidenced by a number of documents she had signed as "Jane the Quene". Her sentence was to "be burned alive on [Hill](Tower)(Tower Hill) or beheaded as the Queen pleases" ([burning](Execution by burning#Historical usage) was the [English punishment](traditional)(Burning of women in England) for [treason](treason) committed by women).;  The [ambassador](imperial)(List of ambassadors of the Holy Roman Empire to England) reported to [V, Holy Roman Emperor](Charles)(Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor), that her life was to be spared.

[[File:Lady Jane Grey letter as Queen.JPG|thumb|left|upright|Official letter of Lady Jane Grey signing herself as "Jane the Quene". [Temple Library](Inner)(Inner Temple Library), London]]

[rebellion](Wyatt's)(Wyatt's rebellion) in January 1554 against [Mary's marriage plans](Queen)(wedding of Mary I of England and Philip of Spain) with [of Spain](Philip)(Philip II of Spain) sealed Jane's fate. Her father, Henry Grey, 1st Duke of Suffolk, and his two brothers joined the rebellion, and so the government decided to go through with the verdict against Jane and Guildford. Their execution was first scheduled for 9 February 1554, but was then postponed for three days to give Jane a chance to convert to the Catholic faith. Mary sent her chaplain [Feckenham](John)(John Feckenham) to Jane, who was initially not pleased about this. Though she would not give in to his efforts "to save her soul", she became friends with him and allowed him to accompany her to the scaffold.

On the morning of 12 February 1554, the authorities took Guildford from his rooms at the Tower of London to the public [execution](execution) place at Tower Hill, where he was beheaded. A horse and cart brought his remains back to the Tower, past the rooms where Jane was staying. Seeing her husband's corpse return, Jane is reported to have exclaimed: "Oh, Guildford, Guildford." She was then taken out to [Green](Tower)(Tower Green), inside the Tower, to be beheaded. According to the account of her execution given in the anonymous *Chronicle of Queen Jane and of Two Years of Queen Mary*, which formed the basis for [Holinshed](Raphael)(Raphael Holinshed)'s depiction, Jane gave a speech upon ascending the scaffold:

Good people, I am come hither to die, and by a law I am condemned to the same. The fact, indeed, against the Queen's highness was unlawful, and the consenting thereunto by me: but touching the procurement and desire thereof by me or on my behalf, I do wash my hands thereof in innocency, before God, and the face of you, good Christian people, this day.

While admitting to action considered unlawful, she declared that "I do wash my hands thereof in innocence". Jane then recited [51](Psalm)(Psalm 51) (*Have mercy upon me, O God*) in English, and handed her gloves and handkerchief to her maid. The executioner asked her forgiveness, which she granted him, pleading: "I pray you dispatch me quickly." Referring to her head, she asked, "Will you take it off before I lay me down?", and the axeman answered: "No, madam." She then blindfolded herself. Jane then failed to find the block with her hands, and cried, "What shall I do? Where is it?" Probably [Thomas Brydges](Sir)(Thomas Brydges), the Deputy Lieutenant of the Tower, helped her find her way. With her head on the block, Jane spoke the last words of Jesus as recounted by [Luke](Gospel of Luke): "Lord, into thy hands I commend my spirit!" The axe then fell and Jane was beheaded in one clean stroke.

Jane and Guildford are buried in the Chapel of [Peter ad Vincula](St)(Church of St Peter ad Vincula) on the north side of Tower Green. No memorial stone was erected at their grave. Jane's father, the Duke of Suffolk, was executed 11 days after Jane, on 23 February 1554. Her mother, the Duchess of Suffolk, married her Master of the Horse and [chamberlain](Chamberlain (office)), [Stokes](Adrian)(Adrian Stokes (Master of Horse)), in March 1555. She was fully pardoned by Mary and allowed to live at Court with her two surviving daughters. She died in 1559.
She was imprisoned in the Tower of London — kept in rooms there (near Tower Green) before being taken out to Tower Green and executed on 12 February 1554.

# Jeff Bauman

*Revision ID: 1160184428 | Timestamp: 2023-06-14T22:26:07Z*

**Jeff Bauman** (born January 2, 1986) is an American author. He lost both of his legs during the [Marathon Bombing](Boston)(Boston Marathon Bombing) attack in 2013 and was the subject of a famous photograph taken in the aftermath of the bombing. The film *[Stronger](Stronger (film))* is based on a memoir of the same name he co-wrote, with actor [Gyllenhaal](Jake)(Jake Gyllenhaal) portraying Bauman.
Jeff Bauman's daughter (born in 2014) is Nora Gail Bauman.

***The Fifth Element***}} is a 1997 English-language French [fiction](science)(Science fiction film) [film](action)(action film) conceived and directed by [Besson](Luc)(Luc Besson), as well as co-written by Besson and [Mark Kamen](Robert)(Robert Mark Kamen). It stars [Willis](Bruce)(Bruce Willis), [Oldman](Gary)(Gary Oldman), [Holm](Ian)(Ian Holm), [Jovovich](Milla)(Milla Jovovich), and [Tucker](Chris)(Chris Tucker). Primarily set in the 23rd century, the film's central plot involves the survival of planet Earth, which becomes the responsibility of Korben Dallas (Willis), a taxicab driver and former [forces](special)(special forces) major, after a young woman (Jovovich) falls into his cab. To accomplish this, Dallas joins forces with her to recover four mystical stones essential for the defence of Earth against the impending attack of a malevolent cosmic entity.

Besson started writing the story that was developed as *The Fifth Element* when he was 16 years old; he was 38 when the film opened in cinemas. Besson wanted to shoot the film in France, but suitable facilities could not be found; filming took place in [London](London) and [Mauritania](Mauritania) instead. He hired comic artists ["Moebius" Giraud](Jean)(Jean Giraud) and [Mézières](Jean-Claude)(Jean-Claude Mézières), whose books inspired parts of the film, for production design. Costume design was by [Gaultier](Jean-Paul)(Jean-Paul Gaultier).

*The Fifth Element* received mainly positive reviews, although some critics were highly negative. The film won in categories at the [Academy Film Award](British)(51st British Academy Film Awards)s, the [Award](César)(23rd César Awards)s, the [Film Festival](Cannes)(Cannes Film Festival), and the [Award](Lumières)(Lumières Award)s, but also received nominations at the [Raspberry](Golden)(18th Golden Raspberry Awards) and [Bad Movie Award](Stinkers)(1997 Stinkers Bad Movie Awards)s. *The Fifth Element* was a strong financial success, earning more than US$263million at the box office on a $90million budget. At the time of its release, it was the most expensive European film ever made, and it remained the highest-grossing French film at the international box office until the release of *[Intouchables](The)(The Intouchables)* in 2011.
The Fifth Element (1997) was directed by Luc Besson.

## Career

### 2009–present: Other roles and mainstream success

[[Efron 2, 2012.jpg|thumb|left|Efron in 2012](File:Zac)]

Efron's next release was [Linklater](Richard)(Richard Linklater)'s period drama *[and Orson Welles](Me)(Me and Orson Welles)*, which premiered at the [International Film Festival](Toronto)(2008 Toronto International Film Festival) in September 2008 and received a wide release in late 2009. The film earned mostly positive reviews from critics. He then played the title role in the supernatural romantic drama *[St. Cloud](Charlie)(Charlie St. Cloud (film))* (2010), which became a moderate success at the box office despite receiving mostly negative reviews from critics.

Efron appeared as a part of the large ensemble cast in [Marshall](Garry)(Garry Marshall)'s ''[Year's Eve](New)(New Year's Eve (2011 film))* (2011), which depicted a series of holiday vignettes of different groups of characters. The film received almost unanimously negative reviews from critics, but became a major success at the box office. He also played a supporting role in the critically successful *[Arts](Liberal)(Liberal Arts (film))* (2012), which premiered at the [Film Festival](Sundance)(2012 Sundance Film Festival) in January 2012 and received a limited release later that year. He also starred in *[Paperboy](The)(The Paperboy (2012 film))* (2012), which premiered at the [Film Festival](Cannes)(2012 Cannes Film Festival) in May 2012 and received a wider release later that year. The film received mixed to negative reviews from critics.

After lending his voice to the commercially successful computer-animated film *[Lorax](The)(The Lorax (film))* (2012), he appeared as the male lead in the romantic drama *[Lucky One](The)(The Lucky One (film))* (2012), based on the [of the same name](novel)(The Lucky One (novel)) by [Sparks](Nicholas)(Nicholas Sparks). The film became a major box office success despite negative reviews from critics. He also starred in the drama *[Any Price](At)(At Any Price (film))*, which premiered at the [Venice International Film Festival](2012)(69th Venice International Film Festival), and the historical drama *[Parkland](Parkland (film))'', which premiered at the [Venice International Film Festival](2013)(70th Venice International Film Festival). Both films received mixed reviews from critics.

Efron's first release of 2014 was the romantic comedy *[Awkward Moment](That)(That Awkward Moment)*, on which he was also an executive producer. The film, which starred Efron as one of three bachelors in New York City, became a moderate commercial success despite receiving mostly negative reviews from critics.

Later in 2014, Efron was seen in the adult comedy *[Neighbors](Neighbors (2014 film))* (2014). The film revolved around a young couple ([Rogen](Seth)(Seth Rogen) and [Byrne](Rose)(Rose Byrne)) who struggle to raise their baby daughter while living next to the house of a wild fraternity led by its president, played by Efron. The film became a major commercial success and earned mostly positive reviews from critics, who also added that Efron had successfully shed his "Disney pretty boy" image.

Efron's only release in 2015 was the moderately successful *[Are Your Friends](We)(We Are Your Friends (film))* (2015), in which he played a struggling DJ. In January 2016, he starred with [De Niro](Robert)(Robert De Niro) in the adult comedy *[Grandpa](Dirty)(Dirty Grandpa)*, about a straitlaced young man who begrudgingly indulges his grandfather's unhinged personality by taking him on a vacation to Florida. The film received mostly negative reviews from critics for its crude humor, but became a commercial success upon its release. He subsequently starred in the comedy sequel *[2: Sorority Rising](Neighbors)(Neighbors 2: Sorority Rising)*, which became a commercial and critical success upon its release in May 2016. The film followed the same couple who team up with their former rival (Efron) to take down a hard-partying sorority led by a freshman ([Grace Moretz](Chloë)(Chloë Grace Moretz)). His third 2016 comedy, released in July, was *[and Dave Need Wedding Dates](Mike)(Mike and Dave Need Wedding Dates).*

[[File:Lily Collins & Zac Efron 3.png|thumb|right|upright=0.9|Efron and *[Wicked, Shockingly Evil and Vile](Extremely)(Extremely Wicked, Shockingly Evil and Vile)* co-star [Collins](Lily)(Lily Collins) in 2019]]

In 2017, Efron starred alongside [Johnson](Dwayne)(Dwayne Johnson) in *[Baywatch](Baywatch (film))*, an action comedy film version of the [series of the same name](television)(Baywatch), released in May. Also in 2017, Efron had a supporting role in two biographical films released in December, *[Disaster Artist](The)(The Disaster Artist (film))*, a comedy-drama directed by and starring [Franco](James)(James Franco), and, as Phillip, in the musical *[Greatest Showman](The)(The Greatest Showman)*. Both were nominated for the [Globe Award for Best Motion Picture – Musical or Comedy](Golden)(Golden Globe Award for Best Motion Picture – Musical or Comedy).

In 2019, Efron played a drug-addled libertine in the [Korine](Harmony)(Harmony Korine) film *[Beach Bum](The)(The Beach Bum)*. He also starred as serial killer [Bundy](Ted)(Ted Bundy) in *[Wicked, Shockingly Evil and Vile](Extremely)(Extremely Wicked, Shockingly Evil and Vile)*, alongside [Collins](Lily)(Lily Collins) as Bundy's girlfriend. The film premiered at Sundance in early 2019 and was released by Netflix on May 3.

In 2020, Efron voiced [Jones](Fred)(Fred Jones (Scooby-Doo)) in Warner Bros.' *[Scooby-Doo](Scooby-Doo)* animated film, *[Scoob!](Scoob!)* In 2021, he won a [Emmy Award](Daytime)(Daytime Emmy Awards) for Outstanding Daytime Program Host for the [Netflix](Netflix) [documentary](web)(web documentary) series *[to Earth with Zac Efron](Down)(Down to Earth with Zac Efron)*.

In 2022, he starred in the survival thriller *[Gold](Gold (2022 Australian film))*, directed by [Hayes](Anthony)(Anthony Hayes (actor)), and headlined the horror film *[Firestarter](Firestarter (2022 film))*, a remake of the [film](1984)(Firestarter (1984 film)) based upon the [of the same name](novel)(Firestarter (novel)) by [King](Stephen)(Stephen King), directed by Keith Thomas. Also that year, he starred in [Farrelly](Peter)(Peter Farrelly)'s Vietnam War–set comedy *[Greatest Beer Run Ever](The)(The Greatest Beer Run Ever)*, which received mixed reviews.

He is set to appear in [Durkin](Sean)(Sean Durkin)'s *[Iron Claw](The)(The Iron Claw (film))*, about the [Erich family](Von)(Von Erich family) of wrestlers.
He won a 2021 Daytime Emmy Award — Outstanding Daytime Program Host — for the Netflix documentary series "Down to Earth with Zac Efron."

[{'section_id': 'johnny_galecki:johnny_galecki', 'section_name': 'Johnny Galecki'}, {'section_id': 'johnny_galecki:early_life', 'section_name': 'Early life'}, {'section_id': 'johnny_galecki:career', 'section_name': 'Career'}, {'section_id': 'johnny_galecki:personal_life', 'section_name': 'Personal life'}, {'section_id': 'johnny_galecki:filmography', 'section_name': 'Filmography'}, {'section_id': 'johnny_galecki:film', 'section_name': 'Film'}, {'section_id': 'johnny_galecki:television', 'section_name': 'Television'}, {'section_id': 'johnny_galecki:music_videos', 'section_name': 'Music videos'}, {'section_id': 'johnny_galecki:awards_and_nominations', 'section_name': 'Awards and nominations'}, {'section_id': 'johnny_galecki:references', 'section_name': 'References'}, {'section_id': 'johnny_galecki:external_links', 'section_name': 'External links'}]

## Personal life

As a teenager, Galecki dated his *Roseanne* (and later *The Big Bang Theory*) co-star [Gilbert](Sara)(Sara Gilbert) (their characters also dated). During their relationship, Gilbert realized she was gay. They remain close friends.

While working on *The Big Bang Theory*, Galecki dated co-star [Cuoco](Kaley)(Kaley Cuoco) for about two years until December 2009 while the two also played a couple on the show. Cuoco told *[Watch](CBS)(CBS Watch)* that they have remained on good terms since ending their relationship.

Galecki owns 360 acres of land in [Margarita, California](Santa)(Santa Margarita, California). His property included vineyards and a log cabin.  In late June 2017, Galecki's ranch was destroyed in a major [wildfire](2017 California wildfires) known as the [Fire](Hill)(2017 California wildfires#Wildfires). Galecki, in a media statement, said wildfire was "the threat ... we live with constantly, which may seem crazy to some but we do so because living in our beautiful, rural area makes it worthwhile".

In August 2018, Galecki started dating Alaina Meyer. [Non-loginwalled link at bibliogram.pussthecat.org](https://bibliogram.pussthecat.org/p/Bl_63oNAvw9) Their son, Avery, was born in November 2019. In November 2020, it was reported that Galecki and Meyer had separated.

## Career

[[Galecki 2008.JPG|thumb|left|upright|Galecki in July 2008](File:Johnny)]

After working in the Chicago theatre scene as a young child, Galecki made his onscreen acting debut in the 1987 CBS miniseries *[Ordained](Murder)(Murder Ordained)* with [Williams](JoBeth)(JoBeth Williams) and future *Roseanne* co-star [Goodman](John)(John Goodman). In 1989, Galecki portrayed Rusty Griswold in ''[Lampoon's Christmas Vacation](National)(National Lampoon's Christmas Vacation)''. In 1990, he was cast as Danny Nash, the son of [Urich](Robert)(Robert Urich)'s lead character, on the [NBC](NBC) comedy *[Dreamer](American)(American Dreamer (TV series))*; the following season, he was a regular cast member on the ABC sitcom *[Billy](Billy (1992 TV series))*, a spin-off from *[of the Class](Head)(Head of the Class)*. He appeared in one episode of [*Blossom*](Blossom (TV series)) in 1991, opposite his future *[Big Bang Theory](The)(The Big Bang Theory)* co-star [Bialik](Mayim)(Mayim Bialik). He played a young delinquent in *[Family Torn Apart](A)(A Family Torn Apart)*, a 1993 TV movie based on a true story about a [killer](serial)(serial killer).

During his run on *Billy*, Galecki began making guest appearances on the hit ABC sitcom *[Roseanne](Roseanne)* as the younger brother of Mark Healy ([Quinn](Glenn)(Glenn Quinn)), who began a relationship with Darlene Conner ([Gilbert](Sara)(Sara Gilbert)). Introduced in his first appearance as Kevin Healy, his name was soon changed to [David](List of Roseanne characters#David Healy). After a few more guest shots, Galecki was named a permanent *Roseanne* cast member from the fall of 1992 onward, after the cancellation of *Billy*. He would remain in the role of David Healy until the end of *Roseanne*'s run in 1997, with the character eventually marrying Darlene and fathering two children with her. Galecki's character on *The Big Bang Theory* would also have a short-lived relationship with Gilbert's character on the same show.

Galecki also appeared in the 1995 music video for the [Matthews Band](Dave)(Dave Matthews Band) song "[Satellite](Satellite (Dave Matthews Band song))".

After *Roseanne* ended, Galecki had small roles in a string of films, including the 1997 summer [film](slasher)(slasher film) *[Know What You Did Last Summer](I)(I Know What You Did Last Summer)* (as the killer's first victim),  *[Bean](Bean (film))* (1997), *[Opposite of Sex](The)(The Opposite of Sex)* (1998), *[Bounce](Bounce (film))* (2000) and *[Sky](Vanilla)(Vanilla Sky)* (2001). He had larger roles in the 1997 film *[Kings](Suicide)(Suicide Kings)* and the 2003 film *[Bookies](Bookies (film))*, a comedy thriller film about four college students. Galecki appeared as a golfer in a 2005 episode of *[Name Is Earl](My)(My Name Is Earl)* entitled "Stole Beer from a Golfer".

In 2005, Galecki played Mark Corrigan in a pilot for a US adaptation of the British sitcom [Show*](*Peep)(Peep Show (British TV series)). He played a character named Trouty on [TBS](TBS (TV network))'s sitcom *[Boys](My)(My Boys)*, and the half-brother of the main characters, sisters Hope Shanowski and Faith Fairfield, in the sitcom *[& Faith](Hope)(Hope & Faith)*. Galecki originated the role of Alex, a male prostitute, in the play *[Little Dog Laughed](The)(The Little Dog Laughed (play))* by [Carter Beane](Douglas)(Douglas Carter Beane), in 2006 at [Stage Theater](Second)(Second Stage Theater). He stayed in the role for the play's [Broadway](Broadway theater) run at the [Theatre](Cort)(Cort Theatre) in late 2006 and early 2007. Galecki said at the time, "At its core, the play is about what we all sacrifice to be successful, whatever our careers or goals." The play was a commercial and critical success, and Galecki won a [Theater World Award](2007)(Theater World Award#2007) for his performance.

[[File:Johnny Galecki at PaleyFest 2013.jpg|thumb|upright|Galecki at [PaleyFest](PaleyFest) 2013]]

Galecki played [Hofstadter](Leonard)(Leonard Hofstadter) in the [CBS](CBS) sitcom *[Big Bang Theory](The)(The Big Bang Theory)*, which ran from 2007 to 2019 and was, for most of its run, among the top three most popular television comedies in the US. Galecki was originally asked to play the role of [Cooper](Sheldon)(Sheldon Cooper), but he felt he was better suited for the role of Leonard, and Sheldon's role was eventually given to [Parsons](Jim)(Jim Parsons). During the show's run, two of Galecki's former *Roseanne* co-stars appeared on the show: [Gilbert](Sara)(Sara Gilbert) (as [Winkle](Leslie)(Leslie Winkle), Leonard's colleague) and [Metcalf](Laurie)(Laurie Metcalf) (as Mary Cooper, Sheldon's mother). Galecki is a [cellist](cello), a talent that was used on the show. Until 2013, Galecki and his *Big Bang* co-stars [Cuoco](Kaley)(Kaley Cuoco) and Jim Parsons each earned US$325,000 per episode.Battaglio, Stephen; Schneider, Michael (August 26, 2013). "What They Earn". *[Guide](TV)(TV Guide)*. pp. 16 – 20. By 2014, the three were earning US$1 million per episode.

Galecki appeared briefly in the 2008 superhero comedy *[Hancock](Hancock (film))*, alongside [Smith](Will)(Will Smith) and [Bateman](Jason)(Jason Bateman). In July 2011, he played a parody version of himself in three episodes of *[Entourage](Entourage (U.S. TV series))*. He also appeared in the film *[Time](In)(In Time)* (2011) with [Timberlake](Justin)(Justin Timberlake) and [Seyfried](Amanda)(Amanda Seyfried).

Galecki appeared in one episode of the [revival of *Roseanne*](2018)(Roseanne (season 10)) on ABC. The show, despite its high ratings, was cancelled after [Barr](Roseanne)(Roseanne Barr) posted a racist and controversial tweet about [Jarrett](Valerie)(Valerie Jarrett). *Roseanne* was replaced by a new program, *[Conners](The)(The Conners)*, which premiered in October 2018 and featured the same cast without Barr. Galecki has occasionally appeared as David on *The Conners*.
He plays the cello — Galecki is a cellist, and that talent was written into his Big Bang Theory character, Leonard Hofstadter.

## Giordano Bruno

In his work titled *Essays upon the Mathematics of Mordente: One Hundred and Sixty Articles against the Mathematicians and Philosophers of this Age* (Prague: 1588), Italian philosopher, cosmological theorist, and Hermetic occultist [Bruno](Giordano)(Giordano Bruno) used the unicursal hexagram symbol to represent *Figura Amoris* ("figure of love") part of the [Trinity](Hermetic)(Hermetic Trinity) in his mathesis.

Giordano Bruno. In his 1588 work Essays upon the Mathematics of Mordente he used the unicursal hexagram to represent "Figura Amoris" (the "figure of love") as part of the Hermetic Trinity in his mathesis.

## Theatre

# List of roles and awards of Tom Holland

*Revision ID: 1159237259 | Timestamp: 2023-06-09T03:49:42Z*

---

[[File:Tom Holland by Gage Skidmore.jpg|thumb|upright|Holland at the 2016 [Diego Comic-Con](San)(San Diego Comic-Con)]]

English actor [Holland](Tom)(Tom Holland) started his acting in theatre with a supporting role in 2008 for *[Elliot the Musical](Billy)(Billy Elliot the Musical)* and was promoted to the title role that year, which he played until 2010. He then made his film debut in the disaster drama *[Impossible](The)(The Impossible (2012 film))* (2012) opposite [Watts](Naomi)(Naomi Watts) and [McGregor](Ewan)(Ewan McGregor). He went on to appear in the films *[I Live Now](How)(How I Live Now (film))* with [Ronan](Saoirse)(Saoirse Ronan) (2013), and *[the Heart of the Sea](In)(In the Heart of the Sea (film))* with [Hemsworth](Chris)(Chris Hemsworth) (2015). He also played [Cromwell](Gregory)(Gregory Cromwell, 1st Baron Cromwell) in the miniseries *[Hall](Wolf)(Wolf Hall (TV series))* (2015).

In 2016, he made his debut in the [Cinematic Universe](Marvel)(Marvel Cinematic Universe) (MCU) playing [/ Peter Parker](Spider-Man)(Peter Parker (Marvel Cinematic Universe)) in *[America: Civil War](Captain)(Captain America: Civil War)* (2016). He would go on to play the role for seven of the franchise's films, including his own standalone films *[Homecoming](Spider-Man:)(Spider-Man: Homecoming)* (2017), *[From Home](Far)(Spider-Man: Far From Home)* (2019) and *[Way Home](No)(Spider-Man: No Way Home)* (2021). He's also starred in the films *[Devil All the Time](The)(The Devil All the Time (film))* (2020), *[Onward](Onward (film))* (2020), *[Cherry](Cherry (2021 film))* (2021) and *[Uncharted](Uncharted (film))* (2022).
He first played the title role in Billy Elliot the Musical in 2008.

#### Hong Taiji

Nurhaci died in 1626, and was succeeded by his eighth son, [Taiji](Hong)(Hong Taiji). Although Hong Taiji was an experienced leader and the commander of two Banners, the Jurchens suffered defeat in 1627, in part due to the Ming's newly acquired Portuguese cannons. To redress the technological and numerical disparity, Hong Taiji in 1634 created his own artillery corps from his existing Han troops, who cast their own cannons in the European design with the help of defector Chinese metallurgists. One of the defining events of Hong Taiji's reign was the official adoption of the name "Manchu" for the united Jurchen people in November 1635. In 1635, the Manchus' Mongol allies were fully incorporated into a separate Banner hierarchy under direct Manchu command. In April 1636, [nobility](Mongol)(Mongolian nobility) of Inner Mongolia, Manchu nobility and the [mandarin](Han)(Mandarin (bureaucrat)) recommended that Hong as the khan of Later Jin should be the emperor of the Great Qing.Tumen jalafun jecen akū: Manchu studies in honour of Giovanni Stary By Giovanni Stary, Alessandra Pozzi, Juha Antero Janhunen, Michael Weiers When he was presented with the [seal](imperial)(Imperial Seal of China) of the Yuan dynasty after the defeat of the last [Khagan](Khagan) of the Mongols, Hong Taiji renamed his state from "Great Jin" to "Great Qing" and elevated his position from Khan to [Emperor](Emperor of China), suggesting imperial ambitions beyond unifying the Manchu territories. Hong Taiji then proceeded to [Korea](invade)(Second Manchu invasion of Korea) again in 1636.

[[File:Sura han ni chiha. Currency of the farther East. No.850.jpg|thumb|upright=1.5|*Sura han ni chiha* (Coins of [Khan](Tiancong)(Hong Taiji)) in [alphabet](Manchu)(Manchu alphabet)]]

Meanwhile, Hong Taiji set up a rudimentary bureaucratic system based on the Ming model. He established six boards or executive level ministries in 1631 to oversee finance, personnel, rites, military, punishments, and public works. However, these administrative organs had very little role initially, and it was not until the eve of completing the conquest ten years later that they fulfilled their government roles.

Hong Taiji staffed his bureaucracy with many Han Chinese, including newly surrendered Ming officials, but ensured Manchu dominance by an ethnic quota for top appointments. Hong Taiji's reign also saw a fundamental change of policy towards his Han Chinese subjects. Nurhaci had treated Han in Liaodong according to how much grain they had: those with less than 5 to 7 sin were treated badly, while those with more were rewarded with property. Due to a Han revolt in 1623, Nurhaci turned against them and ordered that they no longer be trusted and enacted discriminatory policies and killings against them. He ordered that Han who assimilated to the Jurchen (in Jilin) before 1619 be treated equally with Jurchens, not like the conquered Han in Liaodong. Hong Taiji recognized the need to attract Han Chinese, explaining to reluctant Manchus why he needed to treat the Ming defector General [Chengchou](Hong)(Hong Chengchou) leniently. Hong Taiji incorporated Han into the Jurchen "nation" as full (if not first-class) citizens, obligated to provide military service. By 1648, less than one-sixth of the bannermen were of Manchu ancestry.
Hong Taiji (Aisin Gioro Hong Taiji), later Emperor Taizong of Qing, proclaimed the Great Qing in April 1636. He succeeded Nurhaci and ruled until 1643.

## Career

As a singer, Lane performed in bars in [Boystown](Boystown (Chicago)) before starting his comedy career circa 2011 at open mics in Chicago. He moved to New York to work as a [artist](storyboard)(storyboard artist) circa 2012. In an interview, Lane stated that it was "the most boring job in the world." He later quit the position to pursue comedy. After being featured in "New Faces" at the 2014 [for Laughs](Just)(Just for Laughs) festival, MTV invited Lane to appear on *[Code](Guy)(Guy Code)*. He was later in *[Off](Joking)(Joking Off)* and was cast in MTV's *Ladylike* along with [Byer](Nicole)(Nicole Byer), Jade Catta-Preta, and Blair Socci. Lane was on a panel for a segment about [Davis](Kim)(Kim Davis) on *[Nightly Show with Larry Wilmore](The)(The Nightly Show with Larry Wilmore)*. In 2018, Lane represented Italy at "The Ethnic Show" at the Just for Laughs festival in Montreal. He is the host of the [Snapchat](Snapchat) comedy *Ghost Hunt*.

Lane is an advocate for the gay community. He has been the victim of several homophobic incidents during his shows. On being an openly gay comedian, Lane reports, "I think it's slowly getting better but it's all such new territory in so many ways. I'm not saying they are not gay comics that have existed — I know these people exist". He added that "I'm just saying this is the first time ever that gay, queer, male comedians are sort of on the spotlight that straight comedians are being seen in. So it's all kind of just new. It's all new and discovered and all new territory. I think it's exciting."

His favorite performance venues in New York City are [Cellar](Comedy)(Comedy Cellar), The Stand, and New York Comedy Club. He is a co-star and creator of the [IFC](IFC (U.S. TV channel)) series *Janice and Jeffrey*.

Lane and [Willmann](Emma)(Emma Willmann) are co-hosts of a queer-themed podcast, *Inside the Closet*. They are both also featured in [Netflix](Netflix)'s *[Comedy Lineup](The)(The Comedy Lineup)*. On May 1, 2018, Lane and [Tortorella](Nico)(Nico Tortorella) were featured on a [*Nancy*](Nancy (podcast)) podcast.
He began his comedy career around 2011 (circa 2011), performing at open mics in Chicago.

### 2019–present: Recent work and Marvel Cinematic Universe

[[File:Simu Liu on The Beaverton.jpg|thumb|Liu on *[Beaverton](The)(The Beaverton (TV series))* in 2019]]

In early 2019, Liu guest-starred in the 100th episode of ABC's *[Off the Boat](Fresh)(Fresh Off the Boat)* as a noodle vendor named Willie. He also guest-starred in an episode of the TV series *[Is Nora from Queens](Awkwafina)(Awkwafina Is Nora from Queens)* as Garbage Boy.

At [2019](Comic-Con)(San Diego Comic-Con), Disney announced that Liu would play the titular superhero [Shang-Chi](Shang-Chi (Marvel Cinematic Universe)) in the film *[and the Legend of the Ten Rings](Shang-Chi)(Shang-Chi and the Legend of the Ten Rings)*, which is set in the [Cinematic Universe](Marvel)(Marvel Cinematic Universe) (MCU). *Shang-Chi and the Legend of the Ten Rings* is Marvel's first film with an [Asian](Asian people)-led cast. Liu had asked about playing the role on Twitter in December 2018 when the movie was revealed to be in development. After several production and release delays due to the [pandemic](COVID-19)(COVID-19 pandemic), the film was released in theaters on 3 September 2021, garnering positive critical reception and achieving commercial success. A sequel is planned.

In September 2021, it was revealed that Liu will lead the English-language voice cast of *[Samurai Soul](Bright:)(Bright: Samurai Soul),* a Netflix anime film which premiered on 12 October. In February 2022, Liu joined the cast of [Gerwig](Greta)(Greta Gerwig)'s *[Barbie](Barbie (film))* film for [Bros.](Warner)(Warner Bros.) and thriller film *Hello Stranger* directed by April Mullen.

Both Liu and NBA player [Lin](Jeremy)(Jeremy Lin) had guest appearances as caricaturized versions of themselves in Malaysian comedian [Chieng](Ronny)(Ronny Chieng)'s [Netflix](Netflix) short *Ronny Chieng Takes Chinatown* (2022). In December 2022, Liu was a guest narrator at [Candlelight Processional](Disney's)(Disney's Candlelight Processional).https://disneyworld.disney.go.com/entertainment/epcot/candlelight-processional/

On April 7, 2023, Liu released his debut single, titled ''Don't''.

## History

[[2022 Entrance.jpg|thumb|323x323px|Salesforce's annual Dreamforce convention in 2022](File:Dreamforce)]

Salesforce was founded in 1999 by former [Oracle](Oracle Corporation) executive [Benioff](Marc)(Marc Benioff), together with Parker Harris, Dave Moellenhoff, and Frank Dominguez as a [as a service](software)(software as a service) (SaaS) company. Two of Salesforce's earliest investors were [Ellison](Larry)(Larry Ellison), the co-founder and first CEO of Oracle, and [Minor](Halsey)(Halsey Minor), the founder of [CNET](CNET).

Salesforce was severely affected by the [bubble](dot-com)(dot-com bubble) bursting at the beginning of the new millennium, with the company laying off 20% of its workforce. Despite its losses, Salesforce continued strong during the early 2000s. Salesforce also gained notability during this period for its "the end of software" tagline and marketing campaign, in which it also hired actors to hold up signs with its slogan outside a [Systems](Siebel)(Siebel Systems) conference. Salesforce's revenue continued to increase from 2000 to 2003, with 2003's revenue skyrocketing from $5.4 million in the fiscal year 2001 to over $100 million by December 2003.

Also in 2003, Salesforce held its first annual Dreamforce conference in San Francisco. In June 2004, the company had its [public offering](initial)(initial public offering) on the [York Stock Exchange](New)(New York Stock Exchange) under the stock symbol CRM and raised US$110 million. In 2006, Salesforce launched IdeaExchange, a platform that allows customers to connect with company product managers.

In 2009, Salesforce passed $1 billion in annual revenue. Also, in 2009, the company launched Service Cloud, an application that helps companies manage service conversations about their products and services.

In 2014, the company released Trailhead, a free online learning platform. In October 2014, Salesforce announced the development of its Customer Success Platform. In September 2016, Salesforce announced the launch of Einstein, an artificial intelligence platform that supports several of Salesforce's cloud services.

In 2019, Salesforce joined the [Jones Industrial Average](Dow)(Dow Jones Industrial Average), replacing energy giant and [Oil](Standard)(Standard Oil)-descendant [ExxonMobil](ExxonMobil). Salesforce's ascension to the Dow Jones was concurrent with that of [Amgen](Amgen) and [Honeywell](Honeywell). Because the Dow Jones factors its components by market price, Salesforce was the largest technology component of the index at its accession. CNN Business |url=https://www.cnn.com/2020/08/31/investing/salesforce-dow/index.html |access-date=2022-08-24 |website=CNN |language=en}}

Across 2020 and 2021, Salesforce saw some notable leadership changes; in February 2020, co-chief executive officer Keith Block stepped down from his position in the company. [Benioff](Marc)(Marc Benioff) remained as chairman and chief executive officer. Indianapolis News  Indiana Weather  Indiana Traffic|language=en-US|access-date=2020-02-28}} In February 2021, Amy Weaver, previously the chief legal officer, became CFO. Former CFO Mark Hawkins announced that he would be retiring in October. In November 2021, [Taylor](Bret)(Bret Taylor) was named vice chair and co-CEO of the company.

In December 2020, it was announced that Salesforce would acquire [Slack](Slack Technologies) for $27.7 billion, its largest acquisition to date. The acquisition closed in July 2021. Journalists covering the acquisition emphasized the price Salesforce paid for Slack, which was a 54% premium compared to Slack's market value, as too high of a premium for the company, with views varying from the premium being too concerning for investors to Salesforce playing the long game.

In August 2022, Salesforce reported second-quarter earnings of $7.72 billion. Upon the German software firm [SAP](SAP) reporting its earnings for the same quarter totaling €7.52 Billion, Acceleration Economy reported that Salesforce had surpassed SAP to become the world's largest enterprise software vendor. This mirrored Benioff's remarks in Salesforce's earnings call, where he stated he looked at "this quarter very much as kind of a milestone".

Salesforce announced a partnership with [Platforms](Meta)(Meta Platforms) in September 2022. The deal called that Meta's consumer application [WhatsApp](WhatsApp) would integrate Salesforce's Customer 360 platform to allow consumers to communicate with companies directly. Seeking Alpha |url=https://seekingalpha.com/news/3884560-meta-platforms-announces-whatsapp-salesforce-integration-to-let-businesses-chat-with-customers |access-date=2022-09-20 |website=seekingalpha.com |date=September 20, 2022 |language=en}}

In November 2022, Salesforce announced it would terminate employees in its sales organization. *[Protocol](Politico#Protocol)* reported that the company would likely eliminate some 2500 jobs.

In November 2022, Salesforce announced its co-CEO and vice chair, Bret Taylor, would be stepping down from his roles at the end of January 2023, with Benioff continuing to run the company and serve as board chair. Within the week, former [Tableau](Tableau Software) CEO Mark Nelson and former [Slack](Slack (software)) CEO [Butterfield](Stewart)(Stewart Butterfield) also announced their departures. When asked about the departures, Benioff stated, "people come and people go"; Salesforce's stock dropped to a 52-week low after Nelson's resignation. Seeking Alpha |url=https://seekingalpha.com/news/3914027-salesforce-crashes-to-52-week-low-as-slack-boss-butterfield-departs |access-date=2022-12-09 |website=seekingalpha.com |date=December 5, 2022 |language=en}}

In January 2023, the company announced a [layoff](layoff) of about 10% or approximately 8,000 positions. According to Benioff, the company hiring too aggressively during the [pandemic](COVID-19)(COVID-19 pandemic) and the increase in working from home led to the layoff. The company will also reduce office space as part of the restructuring plan. The same month brought an announcement from [investor](activist)(activist investor) [Management](Elliott)(Elliott Investment Management) that it would acquire a "big stake" in the company. Elliott Management Takes Big Stake in Salesforce |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/activist-takes-big-stake-in-salesforce-11674432531 |access-date=2023-01-23 |website=WSJ |language=en-US}}
Marc Benioff — he (a former Oracle executive) founded Salesforce in 1999 along with Parker Harris, Dave Moellenhoff, and Frank Dominguez.

# The Parent Trap (1998 film)

*Revision ID: 1159548367 | Timestamp: 2023-06-11T01:40:24Z*

---

| based_on       =

| producer       = Charles Shyer

| starring       =

| cinematography = [Cundey](Dean)(Dean Cundey)

| editing        = [A. Rotter](Stephen)(Stephen A. Rotter)

| music          = [Silvestri](Alan)(Alan Silvestri)

| studio         = [Disney Pictures](Walt)(Walt Disney Pictures)

| distributor    = [Vista Pictures Distribution](Buena)(Buena Vista Pictures Distribution)

| released       =

| runtime        = 128 minutes

| country        = United States

| language       = English

| budget         = $15 million IndieWire|url=https://www.indiewire.com/2014/05/heroines-of-cinema-these-10-female-filmmakers-prove-why-hollywood-studios-should-change-their-tune-25966/|date=May 29, 2014|website=[IndieWire](IndieWire)|access-date=December 25, 2016}}

| gross          = $92.1 million

}}

***The Parent Trap*** is a 1998 American [comedy](romantic)(romantic comedy) film directed and co-written by [Meyers](Nancy)(Nancy Meyers), and produced and co-written by [Shyer](Charles)(Charles Shyer). It is a [remake](remake) of the [film of the same name](1961)(The Parent Trap (1961 film)) and an adaptation of [Kästner](Erich)(Erich Kästner)'s 1949 German novel *[and Lottie](Lisa)(Lisa and Lottie)* (*Das doppelte Lottchen*).

[Quaid](Dennis)(Dennis Quaid) and [Richardson](Natasha)(Natasha Richardson) star as a divorced couple who separated shortly after their identical twin daughters' birth; [Lohan](Lindsay)(Lindsay Lohan) stars (in her film debut) as both twins, Hallie Parker and Annie James, who are fortuitously reunited at summer camp after being separated at birth. [Swift](David)(David Swift (director)) wrote the screenplay for the original 1961 film based on *Lottie and Lisa*. Swift is credited along with Meyers and Shyer as co-writers of the 1998 version.

The film premiered in Los Angeles on July 20, 1998, and was theatrically released in the United States on July 29, and was a box-office hit, grossing $92.1 million against a $15 million budget. It received positive reviews from critics, with Lohan's performance, in particular, earning high praise.
The 1998 remake of The Parent Trap was directed by Nancy Meyers.

## Personal life

At the time of his death, Duncan was dating reality television personality [Manigault](Omarosa)(Omarosa Manigault). His family later claimed that Omarosa changed his [and testament](will)(will and testament). They also claimed that Omarosa manipulated Duncan in his final days, lied about their engagement, and sold his belongings without the family's knowledge. In 2013, Manigault appeared in the cast of *[All-Star Celebrity Apprentice](The)(The Apprentice (U.S. season 13))* and played in Duncan's honor for his favorite charity and one he had benefited from himself, the [Duncan Children's Center](Sue)(Sue Duncan Children's Center). In episode two of the season, Manigault won $40,000 for the charity.

Duncan trained in [jiu-jitsu](Brazilian)(Brazilian jiu-jitsu) at the [Academy](Gracie)(Rener Gracie) in [California](Torrance,)(Torrance, California) and held a purple belt in the discipline.
He trained in Brazilian jiu-jitsu — he held a purple belt from the Gracie Academy in Torrance, California.

### 2002–2008: Velvet Revolver

[[File:Velvet Revolver live in London 5 June 2007 03.jpg|thumb|right|180px|Slash and [Weiland](Scott)(Scott Weiland) during a [Revolver](Velvet)(Velvet Revolver) concert in [London](London) in 2007]]

In 2002, Slash reunited with [McKagan](Duff)(Duff McKagan) and [Sorum](Matt)(Matt Sorum) for a [Castillo](Randy)(Randy Castillo) tribute concert. Realizing that they still had the chemistry of their days in Guns N' Roses, they decided to form a new band together. Former Guns N' Roses guitarist [Stradlin](Izzy)(Izzy Stradlin) was initially involved, but left after the others decided to find a lead singer. [Kushner](Dave)(Dave Kushner), who had previously played with McKagan in [Loaded](Loaded (band)), then joined the band on rhythm guitar. For many months, the four searched for a lead singer by listening to offered demo tapes, a monotonous process documented by [VH1](VH1). Eventually, former [Temple Pilots](Stone)(Stone Temple Pilots) vocalist [Weiland](Scott)(Scott Weiland) joined the band.

In 2003, Velvet Revolver played several concerts during the summer and released their first single, "[Me Free](Set)(Set Me Free (Velvet Revolver song))". In June 2004, they released their debut album, *[Contraband](Contraband (Velvet Revolver album))*, which debuted at No.1 on the U.S. chart and sold two million copies, re-establishing Slash as a mainstream performer. A year-and-a-half-long tour followed in support of the album. In 2005, the band was nominated for three Grammy Awards: Rock Album of the Year, Rock Song, and Hard Rock Performance for their *Contraband* single "[Slither](Slither (song))" which won their first and only Grammy. In July 2007, Velvet Revolver released their second album, *[Libertad](Libertad (Velvet Revolver album))*, and embarked on a second tour. During a show in March 2008, Weiland announced to the audience that it would be the band's final tour; he was fired from the band in April 2008 and Slash insisted "chemical issues" led to the split. The following month Weiland rejoined Stone Temple Pilots. Despite Weiland's departure, Velvet Revolver did not officially disband.

In early 2010, Velvet Revolver began writing new songs and auditioning new singers. By January 2011, the band had recorded nine demos, and was reportedly due to make a decision on their singer. However, the following April, Slash stated that they had been unable to find a suitable singer and that Velvet Revolver would remain on hiatus for the next few years while its members focus on other projects.
Slash co-founded the supergroup Velvet Revolver with vocalist Scott Weiland in 2002.

### Early career (NASA)

Rober joined [NASA](NASA)'s [Propulsion Laboratory](Jet)(Jet Propulsion Laboratory) (JPL) in 2004. He worked there for nine years, seven of which were spent working on the [rover](Curiosity)(Curiosity (rover)), which is now on [Mars](Mars). He designed and delivered hardware on several JPL missions, including AMT, [GRAIL](Gravity Recovery and Interior Laboratory), [SMAP](Soil Moisture Active Passive), and [Science Laboratory](Mars)(Mars Science Laboratory). While at NASA, Rober was one of the primary architects for "JPL Wired", which was a comprehensive knowledge capture [wiki](wiki). He published a case study about applying wiki technology in a high-tech organization to develop an "Intrapedia" for the capture of corporate knowledge.
He worked for seven years on the Curiosity rover (the Mars Science Laboratory rover).

### Formation and early years

Accenture began as the business and technology consulting division of accounting firm [Andersen](Arthur)(Arthur Andersen) in the early 1950s when it conducted a feasibility study for [Electric](General)(General Electric) to install a computer at [Park](Appliance)(Appliance Park) in [Kentucky](Louisville,)(Louisville, Kentucky), which led to GE's installation of a [I](UNIVAC)(UNIVAC I) computer and printer, believed to be the first commercial use of a computer in the U.S. [Glickauf](Joseph)(Joseph Glickauf), an early pioneer of computer consulting, held a position as head of Arthur Andersen's administrative services division.
Accenture originated as the business and technology consulting division of the accounting firm Arthur Andersen.
